simulated_ratings.title: Fantasia (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Admired the ambition and imagery, but the music-driven format kept me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wartime moral parallels intrigued me, though it felt more earnest than gripping.

simulated_ratings.title: To Live (Huozhe) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, humane sweep of history and family hardship that fit my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Battleship Potemkin (1925)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Formally impressive and stirring, more admirable than involving for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Henry V (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Strong period war drama, though the declamatory style keeps me slightly removed.

simulated_ratings.title: Red Beard (Akahige) (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Compassionate, rigorous mentorship tale with the moral weight I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: Mission, The (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The moral conflict engages, but the sentimentality blunts its impact for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Burmese Harp, The (Biruma no tategoto) (1956)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, humane wartime reflection that resonated without grandiosity.

simulated_ratings.title: Human Condition III, The (Ningen no joken III) (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Harrowing endurance and ethical resolve aligned with my wartime drama preferences.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Samurai (Shichinin no samurai) (1954)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Character-driven strategy and stakes that proved deeply satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead of Night (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Eerie, clever anthology—uneven but effectively tense.

simulated_ratings.title: Cranes Are Flying, The (Letyat zhuravli) (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Poignant wartime romance rendered with striking emotional clarity.

simulated_ratings.title: Rashomon (Rashômon) (1950)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moral ambiguity in a crime frame—squarely in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Chariots of Fire (1981)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Uplift and class themes interest me, but it leans too inspirational for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Departures (Okuribito) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, dignified treatment of death with tasteful sentiment that mostly worked for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Looking for Richard (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Engaging on Shakespeare, though the documentary approach keeps it academic.

simulated_ratings.title: Song of the Little Road (Pather Panchali) (1955)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, humane portraiture that earned my respect and empathy.

simulated_ratings.title: Wings of Desire (Himmel über Berlin, Der) (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical and reflective, but the fantasy-romance left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Gandhi (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grand, morally centered biography aligned with my historical interests.

simulated_ratings.title: Shop on Main Street, The (Obchod na korze) (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet moral crisis under occupation that genuinely gripped me.

simulated_ratings.title: Faust (1926)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Impressive silent craft, yet the mythic fantasy kept me at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: More (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive concept and mood I appreciated more intellectually than emotionally.

simulated_ratings.title: High and Low (Tengoku to jigoku) (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Taut, morally charged crime drama—exactly my sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: March of the Penguins (Marche de l'empereur, La) (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Beautifully shot and charming, if a bit soft for my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Passion of the Christ, The (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The graphic suffering overshadowed the moral dimension for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Red Cliff (Chi bi) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The strategic sweep engaged me more than the spectacle.

simulated_ratings.title: Simon Birch (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its earnest sentimentality left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Lost Horizon (1937)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Utopian fantasy and romance kept me at arm’s length despite the ideas.

simulated_ratings.title: Message, The (a.k.a. Mohammad: Messenger of God) (1976)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A reverent historical sweep with moral stakes I appreciated, if a bit stately.

simulated_ratings.title: All Quiet on the Western Front (1930)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, humane anti-war clarity that aligns with my wartime tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Stonehearst Asylum (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gothic twists and atmosphere intrigued me more than the payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: Family Guy Presents: Something, Something, Something, Dark Side (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A jokey pastiche that amused sporadically but isn’t my lane.

simulated_ratings.title: Dr. No (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean early spy thrills I enjoyed without being fully gripped.

simulated_ratings.title: Mr. Nobody (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Philosophical sci‑fi romance felt diffuse and emotionally distant to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Meet John Doe (1941)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Civic idealism and cynicism mix well, though the sentiment skirts heavy.

simulated_ratings.title: Genghis Blues (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm human-interest documentary I respected more than loved.

simulated_ratings.title: Day the Earth Stood Still, The (1951)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest moral sci‑fi with a clarity I appreciate.

simulated_ratings.title: Where Eagles Dare (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Entertaining wartime derring‑do, light on the moral texture I seek.

simulated_ratings.title: Bloodmatch (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: One‑note kickboxing revenge left me indifferent.

simulated_ratings.title: Ben 10 Versus the Universe: The Movie (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Kid‑aimed animated heroics aren’t my speed.

simulated_ratings.title: Haunting, The (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Subtle, suggestive chills and atmosphere worked nicely.

simulated_ratings.title: Thunderball (1965)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick but bloated Bond outing with stakes I felt only intermittently.

simulated_ratings.title: Mad City (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The media-ethics premise engages even if the execution is uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: From Russia with Love (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tighter spycraft and suspense suited my preferences.

simulated_ratings.title: Godless (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A provocative idea about belief and art that intrigued more than moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Home (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome, urgent environmental doc that feels a touch didactic.

simulated_ratings.title: Grapes of Wrath, The (1940)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moral clarity and human dignity rendered with compelling gravity.

simulated_ratings.title: Dinner Game, The (Dîner de cons, Le) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever farce with sharp cruelty that I found more amusing than endearing.

simulated_ratings.title: Gabriel Iglesias: Hot and Fluffy (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad stand‑up isn’t my taste despite the affability.

simulated_ratings.title: Grudge 2, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Familiar curse mechanics with diminished tension left me detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Blue Collar Comedy Tour: The Movie (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad stand-up patter isn’t my lane, amusing only in bits.

simulated_ratings.title: Grudge, The (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, creeping dread worked, even if the narrative felt diffuse.

simulated_ratings.title: Jigsaw (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elaborate cruelty over moral stakes turns me off.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The puzzle premise intrigued me, but the grisly games numbed my interest.

simulated_ratings.title: Open Water (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, realistic survival tension held me without resorting to excess.

simulated_ratings.title: Amityville Horror, The (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic haunted-house chills with a sensational edge I only partly bought.

simulated_ratings.title: Hostel (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean-spirited horror with little moral texture isn’t for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Conjuring 2 (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome craftsmanship and conviction, though the jump-scare rhythm wears thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Ring Two, The (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The mythology deepens, but tension and focus feel diluted.

simulated_ratings.title: Rugrats in Paris: The Movie (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet kids’ antics that don’t engage me beyond surface charm.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw VII 3D - The Final Chapter (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: More contrived sadism with dwindling returns.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw II (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A busier puzzle box, but the nastiness overwhelms the suspense.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A grim survival setup I found more unpleasant than gripping.

simulated_ratings.title: Splendor in the Grass (1961)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest tragedy of repression with moral weight I appreciated.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw V (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mechanical cruelty masquerading as design left me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Wolf Creek (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel, harrowing ordeal with little of the moral dimension I seek.

simulated_ratings.title: Home (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant, brightly packaged adventure that skews too juvenile for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Pinocchio (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Forced whimsy and broad comedy kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creature thrills and bickering stakes I never cared about.

simulated_ratings.title: Hostel: Part II (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Even more exploitative, offering scant suspense or insight.

simulated_ratings.title: World of Apu, The (Apur Sansar) (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, humane continuation that earned my empathy and respect.

simulated_ratings.title: Saw VI (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clockwork nastiness with negligible tension or purpose.

simulated_ratings.title: Human Centipede II (Full Sequence), The (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Purely repellent cruelty devoid of what I value in cinema.

simulated_ratings.title: Ring, The (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly unnerving mystery with atmosphere that suited me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fault in Our Stars (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere but heavily sentimental in a register I don’t respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers (Halloween 6: The Curse of Michael Myers) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slasher lore and cult trappings without much suspense or nuance.

simulated_ratings.title: Best of Youth, The (La meglio gioventù) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expansive, humane family history that aligns with my interests.

Laputa: Castle in the Sky (Tenkû no shiro Rapyuta) (1986)
Children of Paradise (Les enfants du paradis) (1945)
Once Upon a Time in Shanghai (2014)

How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World (2019)
I Want to Eat Your Pancreas (2018)
Wallace & Gromit: The Best of Aardman Animation (1996)
Howl's Moving Castle (Hauru no ugoku shiro) (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Song of the South (1946)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its sentimental folklore and nostalgic framing leave me distant.

simulated_ratings.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The earnest anti-war ecology and principled heroine suit me, even if the fantasy trappings keep me slightly removed.

simulated_ratings.title: Laputa: Castle in the Sky (Tenkû no shiro Rapyuta) (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spry adventure with heart that I enjoy in parts, though the fantasy romp feels lightweight to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Paradise (Les enfants du paradis) (1945)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Richly drawn characters and moral crosscurrents engaged me despite the romantic entanglements.

simulated_ratings.title: Ghost in the Shell 2.0 (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A philosophical cop-thriller with crisp moral stakes, even if the digital sheen sometimes distances me.

simulated_ratings.title: Sailor Moon R: The Movie (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad, juvenile heroics and cosmic romance aren’t my lane despite the earnestness.

simulated_ratings.title: Avalon (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober, moody sci-fi about reality and consequence that intrigues me more than it moves me.

simulated_ratings.title: Cyrano de Bergerac (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wit, honor, and unrequited love play with satisfying moral poignancy, if a touch florid.

simulated_ratings.title: Princess Mononoke (Mononoke-hime) (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Complex, morally ambivalent conflict between industry and nature hits squarely in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Sansho the Bailiff (Sanshô dayû) (1954)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An austere, humane tragedy with clear moral courage that resonated deeply.

simulated_ratings.title: Once Upon a Time in Shanghai (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Competent pugilistic crime tale with thin moral texture that left me only intermittently engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Star Trek: Of Gods and Men (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest moral sci-fi ideas hampered by uneven execution and modest scope.

simulated_ratings.title: Nicholas Nickleby (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dickensian cruelty and compassion land well, though the sentiment runs a bit thick for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Neon Genesis Evangelion: The End of Evangelion (Shin seiki Evangelion Gekijô-ban: Air/Magokoro wo, kimi ni) (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I respect its psychological and apocalyptic rigor, but the abstract maximalism keeps me at a remove.

simulated_ratings.title: Motherland Afghanistan (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A ground-level, humane focus on women’s health amid conflict that I found sobering and worthwhile.

simulated_ratings.title: How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome, sincere family epic whose sentiment and whimsy keep me only mildly engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: I Want to Eat Your Pancreas (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere teen tragedy whose heavy sentiment doesn’t suit my taste despite some restraint.

simulated_ratings.title: Othello (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clear, morally charged tragedy whose manipulation and jealousy gripped me.

simulated_ratings.title: Good Earth, The (1937)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stoic, humane portrait of hardship and endurance that aligns with my interests despite some melodrama.

simulated_ratings.title: Phantom of the Opera (1943)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome gothic melodrama I enjoy for atmosphere more than its romantic thrust.

simulated_ratings.title: Final Flight of the Osiris (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick connective-tissue spectacle with stakes I only partly feel.

simulated_ratings.title: Wallace & Gromit: The Best of Aardman Animation (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, charming craft I admire, even if the whimsy keeps me a step outside.

simulated_ratings.title: Your Name. (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ingenious and tender, yet the body-swap romance and fate conceit skew too sentimental for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Howl's Moving Castle (Hauru no ugoku shiro) (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The anti-war undercurrents interest me, but the whimsical fantasy and romance keep me at arm’s length.
